turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, Justices of the Supreme Court of the United States.

As has been safely apparent from the discussion of the problem before this Court today is a great historical significance not because the Georgia legislature is the only legislative body which has ever refused to seat a member in judging his qualifications.
But because this is the first time insofar as we have been able to ascertain that the issues presented in this case have ever been before the Supreme Court.
Indeed historically, there seems to be a lack of precedent for this case to be here.

But I should concede in candor that in view of recent decisions of this Court, history alone does not control nor indeed should it control and without waiting or conceding any of the arguments raised in our brief, I will consign our argument to the basic constitutional questions raised and the basic constitutional rights of Mr. Bond which this Court may find it necessary to determine.
When the Julian Bond's story broke the New York Times interviewed Louie Loreman who was one of the five socialist who were expelled by the New York Legislature in 1919.
It inquired why no court action had been taken by them at that time, said Mr. Loreman.
We regard the concept of separation of powers as far more important than own case.
If judges can decide who can seat in the legislature then they can decide who shouldn't seat.
This would be a much greater offense to a Democratic Government than anything a stupid majority of legislators might do in an individual case.
So I think it will be readily agreed therefore that this is a first impression case before this Court.
And that is it may for the first time construe the power of a legislative body in determining qualification of its selected membership, it is of paramount importance.

The question concerning Mr. Bond's election and his subsequent election except for the fact that he has not been refused a seat by the Second Legislature, it is merely the committee's recommendation which will go to the General Assembly next January.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That is the newly elected assembly?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes sir.
He is not in dispute.
Mr. Bond has been (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Does that mean this recent one go to the newly elected assembly that was -- he was elected last year?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: No sir, there has been no contest to his election on --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The second action you said was a committee recommendation.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And this -- is that recommendation was to be acted upon by the legislator elected last Tuesday?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: This may or may not include Mr. Bond?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes sir, that's right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, has he been exuded for two of his terms or (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: He was excluded for the term upon which this suit is predicated.
Then --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Was this the first one?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes.
Then the governor in conformity with the law called a special election.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Mr. Bond ran and was overwhelmingly reelected.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: When was that?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: That was this year March, the legislature was in recess, a special (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: March of what year?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: March of what year?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: March of 1966.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes sir.
The legislature was in recess, a committee convened and met and made a recommendation that he'd be not seated but it has not been acted on by the legislative which doesn't --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well Mr. Attorney General, I'm a little confused about this.
Isn't that -- that legislature is now out of office, isn't it?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: It will be --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Or will be on January --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, what action can the legislature -- the newly elected legislature take in respect of his being seated in the legislature that no longer exists.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Whatever it determines Your Honor, if I understand the reason that he ran was to be able to serve on committees during the recess of the legislature.
But actually as the -- Your Honor points out, any recommendation of this committee would not be binding on the newly convened legislature.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well I can't even see what the newly convened legislature can now do about his being seated in the legislature which no longer exists.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: They cannot.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well then, is this recommendation then to -- have any relation to his election last Tuesday?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: You mean the recommendation of the legislature this year, this committee?
No sir, I don't think it has anything to do with this.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well I must say then I don't understand what possible action the newly elected legislature can take in this recommendation.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: The newly elected legislature, if the time -- if his qualification to our challenge they may or may not be challenged.
But I think if that time would have to determine it for themselves.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Did Mr. Bond show up after the special election and offered to take the oath of office?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I would presume yes sir that he did present himself.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And permission was refused?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: So that that is --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I think that --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- official state action?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: So that as of now, with respect to Mr. Bond's second election, that is the special election, we have a closed book.
Now we -- that is to say in a sense that he offered to take the election -- take the oath of office and the state refused to permit him to take the oath of office.
And so that stands the same footing as the first one.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I think you are correct Your Honor, yes sir.
We will therefore try to the deal is -- briefly as possible in the time allotted us, those constitutional questions which we think may concern the Court in arriving at a decision.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What do you understand the word qualification to mean in your constitution?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I understand the word qualifications, may it please the Court, to mean the qualifications imposed in the Georgia constitution and also the qualification imposed by Article VI, Clause 3 of the United States Constitution.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Does either one of those includes a disqualification on account of views?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: No sir.

The qualifications of the Georgia constitution, may it please the Court, opposed which are usually contained in state constitutions saying that he'd be a citizen of the United States 21 years of age, citizen of Georgia for two years and the rest of that -- of the county from which elected of the district from which elected for one year and it has other provisions in the Georgia constitution.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And as if it would require a trial in order to determine the constitution?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Any in the Georgia constitution?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes, any qualification as it requires a trial.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Nothing except the qualification as contained in the Georgia constitution Your Honor that he'd be bound to support the constitution of the United States.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So that's all?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Anything about good character?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: No sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So that you really have --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: We have --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- very nominal qualification.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I would think that with the qualification of Article VI, Clause 3 of the Federal Constitution, we do have nominal qualifications.
Of course he can't owe money to the State and there are some specific --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did they say that?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: He can't owe money to the State.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: That's right, cannot be indebted to the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well that -- that's not involved here?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: That is not involved here, no sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is there anyone that is involved here?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: The Court please, the qualifications contained in the Federal Constitution, Article VI, Clause 3 which requires that a state legislator be bound to support the constitution of the United States because of a -- the supremacy clause of the U.S. constitution, we think to be a paramount qualifications.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You don't think do you that that was a -- to be construed as meaning or the man swears he will never express any views hostiles to Government policy.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: No sir, I think that it'd be construction of course, it's up to this Court to construe that provision of the constitution.
But I think that that provision means and is a qualification that a person be bound to support the constitution of the United States.
It's imposed on the Congress upon the legislative and executive branch and the judiciary of the several States in Article VI, Clause 3.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But of course the number of the judiciary are they -- not the judiciary, the legislative body, do express their views, they have vigorously against policies of the Government?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So that you can't be taken to -- forbid that, can they?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: No sir, I don't think it can be taken to forbid the expression of views.
But I think if a person which I will try to develop, I think if a challenge is unopposed that the legislature can hear it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Legislature can what?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Can hear evidence for the purpose of determining qualifications.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: As to mean whether the legislature agrees with the views --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Well I don't --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- expressed.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: The Court knows I can't state that nearly because the legislature merely disagreed with the views of a member who was being seated that he could not be seated.

But I think that the legislature in a hearing to determine the qualifications under Article VI, Clause 3 of the United States Constitution that a member of a state legislature be bound to support the constitution of the United States can hear any relevant evidence which bears on his qualifications to be bound to support the constitution of the United States.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, but there's a question Mr. Attorney General as to what being bound to support means.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes sir and --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Would you say for a moment that a legislature -- a legislator is being unfaithful to his oath if he says, "I think the First Amendment should be amended.
I don't agree with it".

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: No sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you think he is -- did you think (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Because his advocating that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That because I think (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: He is advocating an amendment of the law within the framework of the constitution.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So you could disagree.
You can disagree with the policy stated in some provisions in the constitution and still support it then.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes sir.
I think the states will also along I think --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So that -- if we are really we're saying then that the -- that Mr. Bond could state his views in opposition to policy, to the policy of the constitution or the policy of the law of the United States?
You concede that?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes I think Mr. Bond can state his views.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But you would say I suppose that if he said, "I will not obey the constitution", that is a wholly different matter?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes sir.
I speak --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you suggest that that what's he said?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I am not trying --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, not (Inaudible) --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Excuse me.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you suggest that that is what he said that he will not obey the constitution?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes sir, I think he advocated violation of the laws.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Although he himself denies that that's what he said.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What language do you point to in this -- in what he said to arrive at that opinion?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Mr. Bond stated as set out in the opinion that he would advocate it that those who violate -- anyone violate the Selective Service Act for any reason which they saw fit.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But let's see where it -- just what he said that's rather important.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Alright sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You know just what he said.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Record page 138.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes sir.
May I read?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, if you please.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: During a taped interview with the representative of the media, Mr. Bond after endorsing the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee statement was asked why he endorsed it and his answer was as follows.
Why?

Endorse it -- this, because I like to think of myself as a pacifist and one who opposes that war and any other war and eager and anxious to encourage people not to participate in it for any reason that they choose.
And secondly, I agree with the statement because of the reasons set forth in it.
Because I think it is so hypocritical for us to maintain that we are fighting for liberty in other places and we are not guaranteeing freedom to citizens inside the continental United States.
Further reading, may it please the Court.

When they asked if he thought his views were at variance with the duties that might be required of him as a representative in the House of Representatives of the State of Georgia, Mr. Bond replied, "Well I think the fact that the United States Government fights a war in Vietnam.
I don't think that I as a second class citizen of the United States have a requirement to support that war.
I think my responsibility is to oppose things that I think are wrong, if they are in Vietnam or New York or Chicago or Atlanta or whatever".

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is that all that you rely on?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is that all you rely on?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I could -- I am sorry, that --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is that all that you rely on to say that he advocated violation of the law and disobedience to the constitution?

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: How about the statements --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: That --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- the SNCC statement on 137?
I suppose that's closer to your point that the statement of the fact that we're in sympathy within the support and then we're unwilling to respond to the draft.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: The -- let me explain to the Court.
This entire statement -- excuse me.
The entire statement of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee was read into the record at the hearing.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: He didn't write that, did he?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: No sir, he didn't write it but he was -- publicity and I don't think he is -- I think if the evidence is uncontradicted that he was a Student -- I mean he was the publicity direct for the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well he said specifically that he endorsed it.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: A what?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Agreed with it.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: At the hearing, --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: -- it was read to him --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: There's no issue that -- what he -- under -- that he endorsed (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: He endorsed it and said he reaffirmed his endorsement of it at the hearing.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, he stated his reasons why he endorsed it.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes.
That's correct.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Would it be constitutional if Georgia or any other state put it in its constitution a provision that no one should be qualified to seat in the state legislature if they were opposed to the national foreign policy?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: They were opposed to the national foreign policy.
I don't think that this Court would hold that was constitutional, no sir.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: What are the constitutional for the state put in this constitutional provision that nobody should be seated who is a pacifist?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Obviously sir, I think the same reason therewith.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: To think what?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I think the same reasoning would apply there.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: There was not?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes sir.
I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Or a socialist?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: The same reason, yes sir.
It is our position, may it please the Court, that the qualifications imposed in the Georgia constitution, all the member of the Georgia -- by the Georgia constitution.

I want to say, but there there's another constitution imposed by the U.S. Constitution Article VI, Clause 3 which of course we joined issue and there's not being a promissory oath that that is a qualification imposed by the framers of our constitution.
Now --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Before this?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: -- why?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: The qualification that an elected representative be bound to support the constitution of the United States.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Be bound to say it?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I think, --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Bound to say (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: -- he would be bound to say it and he would be, if he -- please the Court, that that would be a qualification that he possessed at that time that he said.
Now, I agree that this issue has not been raised.
I've learned a great deal about the -- I think our constitution in studying this facts in this case.
But may I suggest to the Court that one of the reasons this issue hasn't been raised is because of the fact that certainly for the past hundred years, we have had orderly government.
We have had a government under the constitution in this country.
And one of my states, Georgia, was one that participated in the Civil War.
But it was only when those members of the legislature violated this oath.

Violated disqualification if you please the Court, that we had chaos in the country, that this is a fundamental point, a fundamental thing that the framers of the constitution wanted, put in to the constitution by the members of Congress, not only Congress but of the state legislators.
May I say in the state --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Mr. Attorney General, a while ago you said that the different with government policy and the policy of the constitution, with purpose is permissible that a man shouldn't be excluded from the legislature for that reason, just for disagreement.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: That's right sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But that you have thought there was advocacy, a violation of the law (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- or of the constitution.

Now, what if the -- in the hearing for -- on Mr. Bond's qualification, Mr. Bond says, "Well, I understand you think that I advocated breaking the law but I assure you I don't -- I didn't advocate it so for as I know and I don't advocate.
And if I did, I renounce what I said, I -- all I mean is that I do not advocate breaking the laws".
Now, did that occur or not?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: No sir.
That line of questioning didn't occur here.
Mr. Bond -- I believe Mr. Bond did say that he didn't encourage others to burn their draft card that he had his own draft card (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, do you think that -- do you think the legislature excluded him because they thought he advocated the breaking of the law and that they didn't believe his disavowal?
Is that what you're bringing up here that he should -- this exclusion should be affirmed because Mr. Bond advocated disobedient to the federal constitution or the federal laws?
Is that it?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: One of the reasons Your Honor.
We think that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well then -- you have to then say the legislature found that he -- didn't believe him on his disavowal?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I would have to say that the legislature in hearing the evidence in judging his qualifications found that he would not qualify to be bound to support the constitution.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, he did say in so many words.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I know but -- I do not advocate that people should break laws.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes sir, he did say that.
That was evidence in his favor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So then why isn't Justice White's question pertinent?
There must have been a finding if they didn't believe that when he said it.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You've already said that that support to constitution doesn't mean that I will not disagree.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You've already --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Of course.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I mean the -- the gloss you put on that is that -- what it means is that the man will not abide by the constitution, would disobey it.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now he says, I don't mean that.
I didn't mean that and I don't mean it.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I think that was for evidence for the House to consider.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: General, you have told us that you're relying on the section of the constitution which requires every state legislator to take the oath to support the constitution of the United States.
Now, is there anything in the constitution that gives a right to anyone to judge the sincerity of a legislator who is willing to take that oath?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: No sir.
May I read the provision of the U.S. Constitution, its very short, Article VI, Clause 3.

The Senators and Representatives before mentioned, and the Members of the several State Legislatures, and all executives and judicial officers, both of the United States and of the several States, shall be bound by Oath or Affirmation, to support this Constitution; but no religious test shall ever be required as a qualification, a qualification to any Office or public trust under the United States.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: My question --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- to you is that do you -- that section, if an elected officer is willing to and offers to take that oath, is there anything in the constitution of the United States that authorizes anyone under any circumstances, to pass upon his sincerity in taking that oath?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Not in the United States Constitution sir, except in that (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And then I would like to know why -- how you jump from that to the fact that the legislature of Georgia has a right to test the sincerity of this man in taking that oath?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Well, may it please the Court.
I have to state my position to that.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Certainly.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: But we -- of course this -- he was -- one of the allegation, one of the challenge unopposed stated that he was not qualified under this provision of the U.S. Constitution and --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Who said that?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: One of the challenges to Mr. Bond's being seated.
And the Georgia --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You mean, he judged that the -- he passed judgment on Mr. Bond to the effect that Mr. Bond would not -- was not sincere in taking that oath.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I think that would be a fair statement, yes sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I think it would be.
But the provisions for the House to judge it -- the Georgia House of course is not in the constitution.
That relates back to the Georgia constitution, the provision that the House shall be that sole judge of the qualification in election of its members.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But now what -- you told us that there is nothing in the Georgia Constitution that directly confers with his taking the oath, have you not?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: The provision of the Georgia Constitution itself which the oath proscribes in the constitution requires to a person to be bound to support the constitution of the State of Georgia and of the United States.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I will -- I asked you the same question then about the Georgia Constitution, is there anything in it that which authorizes anyone to pass upon the sincerity of a person who takes the oath as prescribed by the constitution?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Not in those words Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well then where -- what do you refer to in the Georgia Constitution that authorizes -- the legislature to pass upon the sincerity of this man in his willingness to take the oath?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: So the only thing that I can assume -- I hope we understand, the legislature acts independently.
The legislature found authority under the qualification provision of the Georgia Constitution, that they were sole judge of the qualifications of a member to that House.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I suppose he would say that the Georgia Constitution at least is construed by the federal court, the majority of the federal court here versus the Georgia law.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Oh, yes sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Have you got any state court decisions on this?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: As to qualifications?

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: We have no state court decisions as construed in this provision of the federal constitution.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, I should suppose that we -- you would go even further than my Brother Harlan suggest and say that the questions of Georgia law are none of the business of this Court and we have to assume that when the state legislature proceeded as it did, it was expressing what the law of Georgia is.
And the only questions for us is, is whether the action of that state legislature violated the United States Constitution.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Isn't that --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I think that would be a fair statement.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Don't you also say that it's not of the judiciary's business any way.
I would think you do if it's a political question.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Well, later on in my argument I --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: -- get -- touch on that issue as to the due process.
So it is our position that the federal constitution provides a minimum qualification, the only qualification there.
May I go back one moment because of course I digress -- you might -- the Court might say is, this is a -- why, why does the U.S. Constitution, why is that important?
Well, why is a state legislature, why is that important?
We have 50 states and I've said in the state legislature and why is that an important position?
Well, may I just very briefly state that a state legislator doesn't just make laws that affect the people in his district.
A state legislator makes laws which affect the people of the entire state of which he is a member without the record modes of transportation now.
A state legislator makes laws which affect the people of the entire nation.

But not only that and to have a constitutional form of government, there is a single member of a state legislature could theoretically be or could theoretically cares the deciding vote in -- as to whether or not the United States Constitution itself, an amendment thereto was ratified.
So it is an important office.

Now when Mr. Bond -- when the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee issued this statement on January the 6th, Mr. Bond made his statements on it and then the legislature of the House convened on January the 5th.
Mr. Bond was an elected representative which we maintain with all except the foul qualification that of being bound to support the constitution of the United States.
There is a necessity for free speech under the constitution.
I don't think I need to repeat that to this Court.
It ensures the process of orderly government.
This Court has imposed limitations on free speech, the known line in cases of obscenity and in the advocacy of law of violation.
It is our position that Mr. Bond in adapting the statement of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee and in his statements thereon advocated violation of the Selective Service Act.
And therefore his speech was not protected but even assuming that his speech was protected, we have to remember Mr. Bond's position, he was not a citizen.
He was a -- in a position of a public servant making comments reflecting upon his qualifications, the qualifications imposed by the Federal Constitution.
The Georgia House, under the Georgia Constitution is the sole judge of his qualification.

And we think that because Mr. Bond of his elective position, he had a great responsibility and obligation than that of an ordinary citizen and that was the qualification which he was to be bound to support the United States Constitution.

And therefore we say, that in this instance and under these circumstances, the Sixth Article, Article VI of the Constitution is of equal rank and dignity with the Bill of Rights of the First Amendment to the Constitution.
And that the legislature in acting as a judge of his qualifications was authorized to treat Article VI of the federal constitution as controlling insofar as determining his qualifications.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Is there been any -- to your knowledge, is there been any debate in the Georgia legislature about the war in Vietnam?
Is there any member of the Georgia legislature --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I'm certain there has been but I have no --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Is there any member of the Georgia legislature who has ever expressed himself as opposed to our participation in that war to your knowledge?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I don't -- I do not know Your Honor.
I do not know possibly there has been.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Because I understand your argument to comes peerlessly close perhaps I misunderstood you, it may come peerlessly close to suggesting that if a legislator suggest such views then he is not qualified to take his oath even if he's subsequently reelected and getting -- supporting with question of removal he is --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: In --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- subsequently reelected and presents himself to take his oath.
He is opposed to the war in Vietnam or that -- that'd be grounds for refusing the -- to allow him to take the oath.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: In the abstract if I may, I certainly don't intended it, conveyed of this Court, the impression that no one can have contrary views.
But I have to relate it back to Article VI of the constitution that --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I understand that sir but don't you have to help us a little bit my --because I understand your position, this case in principle is as if Mr. Bond set out here to take the oath and at the same time he said, "I am not going to observe the oath, I am not going to obey the constitution of the United States".
That it seems to me is the principle that you're presenting to us, right?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Now, don't you have to tell us just where Mr. Bond made such a statement that you alleged to be contrary to the oath, as to where it is and what precisely you're relying on?
You read -- I know you referred the two passages but -- and if those are all that you're relying on, well, we ought to know that.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Well, I will cover that in -- on the next page in just a moment --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: -- in the record that we have Your Honor.
We state that the Georgia House was the judge of Mr. Bond's qualification.
It was sitting as a sole tribune or judicial body who were authorized to determine his qualifications.
We say however that the Court should protect Mr. Bond's constitutional rights but should not substitute its judgment for the House in judging qualifications.

Now back to question Justice Fortas, this statement by the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee of course which I -- I'm not going to read this to the Court because it's of -- about two pages long and my time is getting very close.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's on page 137, that --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- statement to which you refer.
Right.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Mr. Bond was called before the House of committee and on page of 111 of the record, the statement would be found that Mr. Bond stated that he was eager and anxious to encourage people not to participate in the war in Vietnam for any reason that they choose.
Now, this was evidenced for the House to consider in judging Mr. Bond's qualification.
He also said -- the record page 41, "I do not advocate that people should break the law".
That was evidenced in his favor but it was also evidence that the House could consider.
He said from the record on page 112, "I don't think that I as a second class citizen of the United States have a requirement to support the law".
This also was evidenced that the House could consider.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What is that statement mean to you?
He has no obligation to support the war.
Or does it mean that no obligation to agree with it?
Does that mean to you that he was not -- that he would break the law in order no to support it?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Sir, I hate to answer you in this manner but I don't think it's important -- is to what it means to me as what it could have meant to the people who were sitting as his judges at that time --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, he has (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: -- for his qualification.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- to take the next sentence?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you know what it meant to him?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: No sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: They have to take that next sentence though Mr. Attorney General, don't you on page 112 after saying, as second class citizen, I don't think that I have a requirement to support that or he went on to say, "I think my responsibility is to oppose things that I think are wrong if they are in Vietnam or New York".
Is that correct?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes sir, wherever --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And so there is some ambiguity there --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: There is --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- as precisely with (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I would concede that, yes Your Honor.
I can't say to this Court --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You're not telling us that you think the -- or are you, that you think the constitution imposes upon him a requirement to support the so-called war because as long as we're talking about constitution there is not a war in Vietnam, Congress has not declared war.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Are you telling us that -- with reference to what appears on page 112 that the United States Constitution imposes upon Julian Bond and on every state legislator and on every member of the United States Senate and House Representatives to support this "war" in Vietnam?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: No sir, I don't think that I could say that it's imposed in all its citizen's right to support the war in Vietnam.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Or every legislator or -- you're differentiating legislators from citizens.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes I am.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And I don't understand why (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I don't say that that statement taken in and of itself, may it please the Court, would authorize it but I think that the legislature was a judge of his qualification.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, he said here, I don't think that I as a second class citizen of the United States have a requirement to support that war.
I supposed --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I think he as a --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- as a second class or a first class or any other kind of a citizen, he -- there's no requirement to support that, our present foreign policy in Southeast Asia, is there?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: No sir, I agree with the Court.
When the --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You agree with the Court but you think that the legislature did not and that therefore they have the right to exclude Mr. Bond?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Sir I think -- if I can just summarize.
I think that the legislature was a judge of his qualification, a 184 members in the vote thought he wasn't qualified, 12 members voted to seat him.
What the standard of review, I think that the lower court was correct in stating a rational basis was the standard of view -- of review.

I don't think we're concern with whether or not another forum might have judged Bond differently but we are concerned with the fact, was there are any evidence upon which the Georgia House could form a rational basis for finding him disqualified under the United States Constitution.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But don't we also have the problem of determining whether the House have the right to judge him on this issue?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I think --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now that --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: That is correct Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now -- alright, what to -- what is their authority for that?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Well Your Honor, we say that the provision of the constitution itself is a qualification, the federal constitution.

And that the House, the Georgia House of Representatives under the Georgia Constitution is a sole judge of the qualification of its members and if therefore the House had a right to judge of his qualification and was the only body that could judge of his qualification as contained in the United States Constitution.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You've said they had this sole right to judge of his qualification?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: We say that that is a qualification, may it please the Court.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Even though it's the (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I'm not trying to avoid the issue (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Even though they imposed an unconstitutional condition?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Now, if they do it in an unconstitutional manner --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do it in an unconstitutional manner, I suppose they --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: If they --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: They say that you are not qualified because of something about you that (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Because they don't like the way (Inaudible) your hair.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes, what about that?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Well, I don't think it would be constitutional and I think this Court could so hold (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible) but supposed he said, I'm going to get the whole of this School Desegregation laws (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I think it would -- wouldn't be -- have a due process, excuse me.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I would supposed to all of these School Desegregation Laws, we shouldn't obey them then and his right to speech on that, would that require --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I think part of it would be possible.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: That if he advocated that other people violate the law then it would be possible to someone to -- and not choose and oppose the challenge to his qualifications.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Then they could put him out on that -- they have been able --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: After the legislature heard it, yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: There hasn't any other done it yet or were there?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: No sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, General I --

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I still (Inaudible) from the Governor's brief that it is a fact.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I understood you to say that if they decided that he wasn't entitled to take his seat because he parted his hair wrong that that would be for an unconstitutional reasons, would that give us jurisdiction to determine whether they have properly ejected him or not?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I think that under the decisions of this Court, that this Court in such an instance as that --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Could what?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Could take jurisdiction, yes under such instances as that.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Where is that dividing line between our jurisdiction and no jurisdiction in judging of the actions of the legislature in this regard?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Well sir as I understand the law would be determined as to whether or not a person's constitutional rights had been violated.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Then we would have jurisdictions?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes sir, as I understand the decisions of this Court.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And if we thought that the legislature had no right to judge of the sincerity of the man in taking the oath, then we would have a right to say so.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: I think Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And nullify the action of the legislature.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes, I think so.
If I may just summarize briefly.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: We say that the qualification imposed in the constitution was judged by the Georgia House.

We don't think Mr. Bond's rights under the First Amendment were violated because we think that the speech -- parts of the speech which he made could be reasonably interpreted as advocating violation of the Selective Service Act.

But even if he -- it'd be determined to the speech of Mr. Bond would have been protected as an ordinary citizen, the qualification imposed by the United States Constitution has equaled dignity with the First Amendment and is not controlling and the House was authorized to determine his qualification.
We think that Mr. Bond was afforded due process.
His constitutional rights were protected as there was some evidence upon which the Georgia House could make its determination of his qualification.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: But Mr. Attorney General, as I understand your previous argument, the statement that now that Mr. Bond advocated violation of Selective Service Act, doesn't seem to be supported by anything in the record.
Do you -- with -- what is your contention, that it is or is not (Voice Overlap)?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Well, it's our contention Your Honor that when he said I -- urged citizens to -- excuse me, I have a reference to it right here to -- he was eager and anxious -- the record page on 111.
Eager and anxious -- was he -- eager and anxious to encourage people not to participate in it, the war, for any reason that they choose.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Do you say that that is advocating violation of the Selective Service Act?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And that's the provisional on which you're relying?

turn.speaker: arthur_k_bolton
turn.label: Mr. Arthur K. Bolton
turn.text: Yes, we would on that, yes sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Boudin.

turn.speaker: leonard_b_boudin
turn.label: Mr. Leonard B. Boudin
turn.text: Thank you.
Mr. Moore will do the rebuttal Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Very well.

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: If it please the Court.
We'll be extremely brief.
I'd like to call the Court's attention to record page 116 in the following language of Mr. Bond.

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir.
With respect to what he meant by his statement in his position.
He says, "I have suggested that congressionally outline alternatives to military draft to extend it to building democracy at home.
The posture of my life for the past five years has been calculated to give me a grip, the ability to participate the formulation of public policies.
The fact of my election to public office does not lessen my duty or desire to express my opinions even when they differ from those held by others".
I think that statement is very significant, it was before the House of Representatives as to what Mr. Bond meant.
Additionally, with respect to our (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Or then he went on to say that I cannot personally participate in the war, no more.

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir, he reiterate it, his pacifist beliefs at that point.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: He reiterated what?

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: His pacifist beliefs, his own objections to war.

But with respect to others, he had in mind encouraging them to seek congressional alternatives to the draft and the Court is familiar with the fact that there are congressional alternatives to the draft, congressionally provided alternatives to the draft.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: There are bills proposed or there any (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: The -- and their right, our (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Our Selective Service law, a person doesn't have a right to say, "Well, I'd rather in the Peace Corps if the Selective Service Act (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: There is alternative service, the Peace Corps is one I think that this statement (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Not under present law, is there?

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That what it seems to me.

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Under the conscientious objective statute (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Oh yes.

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: The other point --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, what basis would Mr. Bond can -- if he were drafted then saying, "I will not go"?

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: His own beliefs would be the only basis.
He may have an out by selecting service into safe -- for example the public health service as an alternative to military service or --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Could you think he could refuse to go to war and still not break the law?

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Well he'd had to be convicted and that would be a different thing.
Does that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, what I mean --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: He could be -- he could not go off to war and still be obeying the law?

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: But he could select one of the alternative services.
Noncombatant military service or service in the forestry service or service in the public health or some other congressionally provided alternative to military draft.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well Mr. Justice Clark just suggested, is a pacifist, he could claim this (Inaudible), wouldn't he?

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And that would solve that problem, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: That would be adequate, yes sir.
The other point (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did he indicate (Inaudible)?

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: He did indicate that he was a pacifist.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: No, but did he indicate anywhere that he would serve or thought he should say --

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: That's not indicated by the record.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And he in effect --

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: No sir.
That he should serve and the question was not put to him as to whether or not he should serve.
He never -- he's never refused to serve.
He did indicate that he had a draft card and he did produced it -- offered to produce the draft card at the legislative hearing.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, he pretty much indicated that he would not participate in the war.
He said, "I cannot participate in war".

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: There's no question about that.
The other thing that I would like to --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, then wouldn't he -- in order not to -- he wouldn't participate in the war, he would have to have some other recognized excuses for not going.
On the conscientious objection that's beyond a religious basis, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Not necessarily, not under the decision of this Court in the Siegel (ph) case but -- perhaps it have --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Perhaps it has anything to do with religion?

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: It would have to have some religious training and belief but not necessarily a belief in the Supreme Being.
If you could prove --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Still has to be on a religious basis?

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Some religious influence on the decision.
It appears from the decisions of a court.
Some religious influence that --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: More than --

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: -- well, as to religious belief.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: More than conscience?

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: But that does -- didn't the draft clause permit a registrant to say, "Well, I will serve in the public health service or the forestry service", or these others?

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: That's my understanding of the law sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But as I understand his statement, it seems to me like the firm authorize a statement, he is against that law, he didn't want to have anything to do with it.
That he doesn't intend to have anything to do with the church.
It seems to me like that's a potential he has that he -- it's a view he has.
Are you depending now on the ground that this statement can be construed in some fashion as meaning that he doesn't want that law violated?

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: I don't quite understand the question but I'm not defending on that ground.
I'm defending on the ground that he has a right under the First Amendment to express those views and not could be excluded from the legislature.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I rather thought his statement sounded like he is proud of his views.

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: howard_moore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Howard Moore, Jr.
turn.text: If I may move on to the note which we'd like to conclude, is that the State, the respondents construe Article VI provision with respect to the oath to be synonymous with support of the Government or support of a particular administration.

The Article itself provide support of the constitution and that's a very meaningful and such as to the distinction that one can't support the constitution in good faith unconscientiously and not support the particular policies of a given administration.
And that dramatizes what I think has been an unconstitutional application of that provision in this particular case.
Thank you.
